item.description: The big question surrounding automation isn't just about economics or technology. It's also about psychology. How do designers make us comfortable with something that can be really scary?
item.title: #642: The Big Red Button

item.description: The world economy is more productive than ever before. A lot of people could work fewer hours and still meet their basic needs. But we don't. Why?
item.title: #641: Why We Work So Much

item.description: On today's show: the screwed-up economics of drought, and why the rational thing to do in California right now is use more water.
item.title: #640: The Bottom Of The Well

item.description: On a visit to Greece, we talk to a guy who found an ingenious place to hoard his cash, a government-protected milk peddler, and a would-be olive oil tycoon.
item.title: #639: Where To Hide €50,000, And Other Stories From Greece

item.description: Today on the show: We're going small. We ask some of the smartest people we know what little thing they would change to improve the world.
item.title: #638: Tweak The World

item.description: The story of the secret battle to create the song of the summer — the music industry's holy grail.
item.title: #288: Manufacturing The Song Of The Summer

item.description: Greece's monetary system is in crisis right now, and the government is closing the financial pipes. The effects are widespread and weird.
item.title: #637: The Last Euro In Greece

item.description: We sit down with a psychologist and a mortgage broker who committed large-scale fraud to try to figure out why respectable people commit fraud.
item.title: #363: Why People Do Bad Things

item.description: What do you do when your country's future is put in your hands? On today's show: The referendum in Greece.
item.title: #636: Yes Or No

item.description: Trade deals like the Trans-Pacific Partnership are often negotiated in secret. On today's show, negotiators tell us what happened when they were locked in a hotel for days and told to hash out a deal.
item.title: #635: Trade Deal Confidential

item.description: A farmer wanted to sell all his raisins, but the federal government said no. So he took it to the Supreme Court.
item.title: #478: The Raisin Outlaw

item.description: We ask three economists: Is there some falling anvil that's about to crush the economy?
item.title: #634: Worst Case Scenario

item.description: The price tag is a fairly recent invention. And it's already on its way out.
item.title: #633: The Birth And Death Of The Price Tag

item.description: How the American auto industry is built on a trade dispute over frozen chicken parts.
item.title: #632: The Chicken Tax

item.description: Stories about a $50,000 loophole, what neighborhoods mean for kids, and what the Six Million Dollar Man would cost today.
item.title: #631: The Long Run

item.description: The story of a 24-year-old kid and the idea he thought would reduce congestion, cut greenhouse gasses and make urban life easier for everyone. Instead, it brought him nothing but trouble.
item.title: #630: Free Parking

item.description: Sam Cohen has made a big business out of buying stuff at big retail stores, then turning around and selling it on Amazon. In an era when stores are profit-maximizing machines, how is that possible?
item.title: #629: Buy Low, Sell Prime

item.description: In the early 1960s, Tom Burrell became the first black man in Chicago advertising. Today on the show, the story of how he changed the way people think about ads and how advertising thinks about us.
item.title: #628: This Ad's For You

item.description: Today on the show, how we got from mealy, nasty apples to apples that taste delicious. The story starts with a breeder who discovered a miracle apple. But discovering that apple wasn't enough.
item.title: #627: The Miracle Apple

item.description: Machines have been taking jobs forever. In the past, when jobs disappeared, new ones were created. But is this time different?
item.title: #626: This Is The End

item.description: What if robots did all the work? In today's show, we imagine a world without jobs.
item.title: #625: The Last Job

item.description: We go out for pizza and meet the latest group of workers getting replaced by machines: servers.
item.title: #624: I, Waiter

item.description: In Greenville, SC, the best job option isn't to compete against the robots, but to make friends with them.
item.title: #623: The Machine Comes To Town

item.description: If you aren't already worried about being replaced by a robot, maybe you should be. Today on the show, three races pit humans against machines.
item.title: #622: Humans vs. Robots

item.description: Today on the show, the true story of the Luddites.
item.title: #621: When Luddites Attack

item.description: While most technology is getting smaller and cheaper, batteries still suck. Today on the show, we learn exactly why, and meet some of the people trying to make batteries better.
item.title: #620: Why Batteries Suck

item.description: You're not allowed to buy and sell organs. So doctors created a different system. Today on the show: how do you decide who gets lungs?
item.title: #372: How Do You Decide Who Gets Lungs?

item.description: Casinos are worried that young people aren't interested in playing slots or other games of luck. They're turning to games that require skill, like basketball.
item.title: #619: The Free Throw Experiment

item.description: We visit the workshop of a meat inventor, who came up with Steak-Umm and KFC's popcorn chicken. And we try to figure out what meat inventors tell us about patents and innovation.
item.title: #399: Can You Patent A Steak?

item.description: In the early 1900s, the president of the largest shoe company in the world tried to create a Utopia for his workers. He called his big experiment in welfare capitalism: The Square Deal.
item.title: #618: The Square Deal

item.description: Today on the show: how a bunch of rational economists try to deal with our feelings. And the story of a man who came up with five simple questions that he hoped would predict the future.
item.title: #617: How Do You Feel?

item.description: Just a few years ago, solar power was an expensive luxury for the environmentally conscious. Now it's a good deal for lots of people. How did solar power get so cheap, so fast?
item.title: #616: How Solar Got Cheap

item.description: How do you make money manufacturing a dry, bland cracker that a tiny percentage of the population eats just one week a year?
item.title: #361: The Matzo Economy

item.description: A 12-year-old girl discovers it can cost a lot more to play video games as a girl. Today on the show: video game economics and a sixth-grade smackdown.
item.title: #615: A 12-Year-Old Girl Takes On The Video Game Industry

item.description: We go on stage at a comedy show and read a bunch of weird economics jokes. We bombed.
item.title: #614: Two Radio Guys Walk Into A Bar

item.description: There's an economic line that separates recyclables from trash. And that line has been moving a lot lately.
item.title: #613: Trash!

item.description: Last week Apple was officially added to the Dow Jones Industrial Average. But just because Apple's in the club now, doesn't mean the Dow is a great measure of the economy.
item.title: #443: Don't Believe The Hype

item.description: Look at the numbers today, and things seem promising for the economy. Jobs and home prices are up. But look under the hood, and you see that in a lot of ways the crisis is still with us.
item.title: #612: The Indicator Strikes Back

item.description: Only one in three students finish community college—even if money is not the problem.
item.title: #611: Community

item.description: Today on the show, a businessman goes to prison, and decides he is going to disrupt the biggest captive market in America.
item.title: #610: The Prisoner's Solution

item.description: Faced with an asset bubble, the creators of Magic: The Gathering came up with a plan—a plan to once and for all conquer the science of bubbles, and make a collectible toy that could live forever.
item.title: #609: The Curse Of The Black Lotus

item.description: We look at the ten most shorted stocks out there, to see what this list tells us about human nature and the economy. Plus, we end our shorting experiment.
item.title: #608: Shorters Gonna Short

item.description: Spirit Airlines is one of America's fastest-growing airlines. It's also among the least popular airlines in America. How can one airline be both things at once?
item.title: #517: The Fastest Growing, Least Popular Airline In America

item.description: Kidnapping is big business in Nigeria. One man analyzed the industry, to find its weak points and better protect the people he loved.
item.title: #607: Captive Market

item.description: The electronic spreadsheet transformed entire industries. But its effects ran deeper than that.
item.title: #606: Spreadsheets!

item.description: In 1929, one man correctly predicted the great stock market crash, for totally the wrong reason.
item.title: #605: 'What Goes Up'

item.description: Today, one man at the center of a high stakes negotiation, a group of poker players try to give their money away and that thing everyone loves to hate: airplane baggage fees.
item.title: #604: Hey Big Spender

item.description: The logistical miracles and wild risks behind getting red roses to your doorstep on Valentine's Day.
item.title: #603: A Rose On Any Other Day

item.description: It's a story of exploding bakeries, a blue eagle, and a guy who may or may not have been drunk.
item.title: #510: The Birth of the Minimum Wage

item.description: Pot is now legal in some states, but on the federal level, it's illegal. The legal gray area means many banks in the U.S. won't even give pot businesses checking accounts.
item.title: #602: Big Weed

item.description: The world is running out of chocolate. But a plant scientist in Ecuador has come up with a solution. But if you love chocolate, you might not like it.
item.title: #601: The Chocolate Curse

item.description: Today on the show, we visit the place where regular people compete to do tiny tasks, sometimes for pennies.
item.title: #600: The People Inside Your Machine

item.description: A man goes looking for the invisible wall that traps poor people in poverty. Finding it almost gets him killed.
item.title: #599: The Invisible Wall

item.description: There have been short sellers throughout history. Today, the story of a man who was the very first short seller. The first person to bet that a stock will go down. It doesn't go well for him.
item.title: #598: The Very First Short

item.description: Today on the show, we ignore the advice of some very smart people and bet against something people love.
item.title: #597: We're Short America

item.description: On today's Planet Money: The gold standard and the Great Depression. It's the latest in our gold series.
item.title: #253: Gold Standard, R.I.P.

item.description: We visit the respected finance writer (and charming curmudgeon) James Grant. He makes the case for going back on the gold standard.
item.title: #252: The Gold Standard

item.description: How one man stumbled into a flaw in Apple's operating system and found a way to hack into the phone you might have in your hands right now. The iPhone 5s.
item.title: #596: Johnny Mnemonic's Secret Door

item.description: And what it has to do with how big your raise is next year.
item.title: #222: The Price Of Lettuce In Brooklyn

item.description: On today's show, we follow up on a few of our stories from 2014.
item.title: #595: The Rest Of The Story, 2014 Edition

item.description: On today's show: The story of two guys who tried to cut the pay of a CEO at a small, pneumatic tool company.
item.title: #594: Board Games

item.description: People have always worked. But the thing we think of today as a job — is actually a recent invention. On today's show, we go in search of the very first modern job.
item.title: #593: Who Had The First Job?

item.description: Today on the show, a special holiday episode about the epic, decades long feud between the two companies that make just about every handbell in the world.
item.title: #592: Bell Wars

item.description: Today on the show, the revolution in Ukraine was supposed to make the country a better place for Western investment. But it ended up sparking a war that is scaring that investment away.
item.title: #591: War? What War?

item.description: Today on the show, the mind games that gyms play with you. From design to pricing to free bagels, gyms want to be a product that everyone buys, but no one actually uses.
item.title: #590: The Planet Money Workout

item.description: On today's show: What it's like to live and work in the most dangerous country in the world.
item.title: #589: Hello, I'm Calling From La Mafia

item.description: How customers use a piece of technology can change what the product is. And what the product is can change the business model. It's a constant dance between customers and sellers.
item.title: #588: The Technology Tango

item.description: Iceland is trying out an idea from the Bible. What happens, when you just wipe debt clean?
item.title: #587: Jubilee! (?)

item.description: How did a barren, icy island become a thriving, modern economy?
item.title: #271: A City On The Moon

item.description: Today on the show, we visit a company where people's job is figuring out how to make stuff get cheaper.
item.title: #586: How Stuff Gets Cheaper

item.description: Imagine a marketplace completely free of government interference. A place with no contracts, no courts and no regulations. Except for one pirate, the Dread Pirate Roberts.
item.title: #585: Chasing The Dread Pirate Roberts

item.description: We got a stack of letters from American citizens who wanted to buy stuff from North Korea. On today's show, we try to figure out who sent the letters, and why.
item.title: #474: The North Korea Files

item.description: Some guys have figured out how to sell Nike sneakers for a better price than Nike. And that's fine with the company.
item.title: #584: What The LeBron?

item.description: There is a crime wave in the West right now. Cattle theft, or as they call it in Oklahoma, cattle rustling, is on the rise. The crime is as old as America, and it's making a big comeback.
item.title: #583: Cow Noir

item.description: There's a tiny town on the border between Ivory Coast and Liberia. On one side, Ebola is raging. On the other side, people are doing everything they can to make sure not a single case arrives.
item.title: #582: Guarding The Secret Path

item.description: There's a term in economics, arbitrage, that basically means free money. It's a risk-free way to buy low and sell high. Arbitrages are nearly impossible to find. Today, two guys who say they did.
item.title: #581: Free Money

item.description: Gas prices have been falling since early summer, but not everyone is happy about it. Today, stories about the people who get the oil out of the ground.
item.title: #580: The Other Side Of The Pump

item.description: In big-time college football or basketball, money is everywhere. Coaches are paid millions. Schools make tens of millions. But it's against the rules for schools to pay athletes.
item.title: #579: Is The NCAA An Illegal Cartel?

item.description: Stealing oil takes a global system. Lots of people are in on it - small time crooks, criminal bosses, oil tankers owners and corrupt officials.
item.title: #578: How To Steal A Million Barrels Of Oil

item.description: Italy is two countries — and two economies — in one.
item.title: #400: What Two Pasta Factories Tell Us About The Italian Economy

item.description: A Republican governor lives the dream. He cuts taxes dramatically in his state, and he promises good times ahead. But the good times do not come. Now he's fighting for his political life.
item.title: #577: The Kansas Experiment

item.description: A lot of computing pioneers, the ones who programmed the first digital computers, were women. For decades, the number of women in computer science was growing. But in 1984, something changed.
item.title: #576: When Women Stopped Coding

item.description: Licensing laws are supposed to protect the public. But they also raise prices and make it harder for people to find work.
item.title: #381: Why It's Illegal To Braid Hair Without A License

item.description: The popularity of fondue wasn't an accident. It was planned by a cartel of Swiss cheese makers, which ruled the Swiss economy for 80 years.
item.title: #575: The Fondue Conspiracy

item.description: Today on the show: The story of a guy who tried to make something of himself by getting into a rough business. And the story of a time when the world went wild for debt.
item.title: #574: The Buffalo Talk-Off

item.description: Prices of new textbooks have been going up like crazy — faster than food, cars, even healthcare. On today's show: why textbooks have gotten so expensive.
item.title: #573: Why Textbook Prices Keep Climbing

item.description: Today on the show: Stories about the secrets of jewelry stores, the problem with World's Fairs and a law signed by Abraham Lincoln that's being used today to go after the largest banks in the world.
item.title: #572: Jewelers, Futurists And Whistleblowers

item.description: On today's show, the psychology of giving. Charities raised $1.4 billion to help rebuild Haiti after the earthquake. But when something like Ebola happens, so far, people look the other way.
item.title: #571: Why Raising Money For Ebola Is Hard

item.description: More than half of all Japanese women quit their jobs after giving birth to their first child. That's more than double the rate in the U.S., and it's a problem for Japan's economy.
item.title: #477: Waiting For Robot Nannies

item.description: Today on the show, we read our homeowners insurance policy — and get to the bottom of all that fine print that nobody every reads.
item.title: #570: The Fine Print

item.description: Alex Blumberg is starting a podcasting business, but he needs a partner. Today on the show, Alex searches for that partner. Hewlett-Packard, Ben & Jerry, and now there's Blumberg and ...
item.title: #569: How To Divide An Imaginary Pie

item.description: We pay for an amazing amount of stuff on the internet with our personal data. Today on the show: The story of two people trying to create online services that won't collect any data at all.
item.title: #568: Snoops, Hackers And Tin Foil Hats

item.description: For years now, the economy has been kind of stuck. The unemployment rate is getting better, but slowly. Household incomes have been falling. Today, stories of two people trying to get unstuck.
item.title: #567: Getting Unstuck

item.description: Zoo animals are different than most possessions, because zoos abide by a fundamental principle: You can't sell or buy the animals. Today: What do you do in a world where you can't use money?
item.title: #566: The Zoo Economy

item.description: The company has transformed China. Also: It means anyone anywhere can build almost anything.
item.title: #565: The Story Of Alibaba

item.description: Today on the show: the signature. It's supposed to say, "This is me." But where did it come from. And why are we still using it.
item.title: #564: The Signature

item.description: Today, we talk to smart, thoughtful people about times they got things really, really wrong.
item.title: #563: "I Was Wrong"

item.description: A California mall straddles the border between two cities — and the minimum wage is higher on one side of the mall.
item.title: #562: A Mall Divided

item.description: The most lucrative majors lead to jobs with salaries over $100,000 a year. The least lucrative lead to salaries of around $30,000.
item.title: #485: What's Your Major?

item.description: Today on the show, the future as seen from the 1964 World's Fair. And how the future actually turned out.
item.title: #561: How The Future Looked 50 Years Ago

item.description: Most U.S. cash is in $100 bills, but you rarely see them. Today on the show, where in the world are all the $100s? And what are they being used for?
item.title: #560: Hunting For The Hundreds

item.description: Today on the show, how a bankrupt city is dealing with the most basic of problems — how to get people to pay their bills.
item.title: #559: Detroit's Water Bill

item.description: On today's show, we look at a huge, often overlooked, surprisingly interesting corner of the tax code: The Earned Income Tax Credit.
item.title: #451: Why Some People Love Tax Day

item.description: A half a billion dollars. A Harvard professor. And, maybe, the end of campaign finance as we know it.
item.title: #558: Spending Big Money To Fight Big Money

item.description: Today on the show: Why most countries in the developing world won't let refugees work. And why Uganda is trying something different.
item.title: #557: Doing Business Like A Refugee

item.description: Today we build our show from three short Planet Money stories. We look at when a dollar is not worth a dollar; publishing without a publisher; and, of course, Ikea.
item.title: #556: Some Assembly Required

item.description: Today on the show, two big theories to answer a little question: Why is the milk in the back of the store?
item.title: #555: Why Is The Milk In The Back Of The Store?

item.description: On today's show, how something as simple as a sandwich sales tax ends up a complicated list of definitions, exemptions and confusion. And what that tells us about the tax code in general.
item.title: #554: How The Burrito Became A Sandwich

item.description: Today on the show, how a New Hampshire hotel filled with boozing economists saved the global economy.
item.title: #553: The Dollar At The Center Of The World

item.description: A ticket to an unpopular movie in an empty theater costs the same as a ticket to a sold-out blockbuster. Why?
item.title: #552: Blockbusters, Bombs And The Price Of A Ticket

item.description: Today on the show, we talk to two guys who say we should get rid of patents. If someone has an idea, anyone else is free to steal it.
item.title: #551: The Case Against Patents

item.description: On today's show, we answer one of the most important questions in finance: What actually happens at the end of Trading Places?
item.title: #471: The Eddie Murphy Rule

item.description: What would it be like if everyone at your office knew what everyone else earned? On today's show, we hear about a company where salaries aren't secret.
item.title: #550: When Salaries Aren't Secret

item.description: Today on the show: how a 13-year-old girl built a business in North Korea.
item.title: #549: A Teenager's Guide to Doing Business in North Korea

item.description: There's a huge gap between the sticker price for college tuition and the price students actually pay. On today's show, we try to figure out why.
item.title: #370: The Real Price Of College

item.description: Planet Money's Steve Henn invited a couple computer guys to tap his internet connection for a week. He was shocked by how much they discovered.
item.title: #548: Project Eavesdrop

item.description: When banks do bad things, the financial cops can fine them or get them to admit guilt. Now, they might try something brand new. Today on the show: how to punish a bank.
item.title: #547: How To Punish A Bank

item.description: Today on the show: stories about bored traders, a bank that charges customers to deposit money, and pawn shops for the rich.
item.title: #546: Fear, Negativity And Pawn Shops For The Rich

item.description: People have moved stuff on pallets for a long time. And for basically 50 years, no one in the U.S. really improved on it. Until they did.
item.title: #545: The Blue Pallet

item.description: One hungry reporter goes on a quest to find out why his package of Peanut Butter M&M's weighs 0.06 ounces less than a package of Milk Chocolate M&M's.
item.title: #544: The M&M Anomaly

item.description: Tax carbon emissions. That's basically the whole plan.
item.title: #472: The One-Page Plan To Fix Global Warming

item.description: There's this big idea floating around right now. The idea is this: get rid of banks. Don't make them safer. Don't make them smaller. Just get rid of them.
item.title: #543: A World Without Banks

item.description: A recent report out of Europe says that Germany is doing really well. And says that doing really well can actually be a big problem, if you're on the Euro.
item.title: #542: Can An Economy Be Too Good?

item.description: Aviation companies want to fly drones along your street and over your backyard. But legally they may not have the right. You own your house, but what about the space above it?
item.title: #541: Who Owns The Air?

item.description: Today on the show we have three radio stories for you about the strange ways people think about the future.
item.title: #540: Great Expectations

item.description: Today on the show: The penny. And the strange spot it occupies in our economy. It's worth almost nothing, but not quite.
item.title: #539: What's A Penny Worth?

item.description: In 1978, a group of farmers in a Chinese village wrote a contract and hid it in the roof of a hut. They were afraid the document might get them executed. Instead, it transformed the Chinese economy.
item.title: #337: The Secret Document That Transformed China

item.description: How much of a brand is real? How much is in our heads?
item.title: #538: Is A Stradivarius Just A Violin?

item.description: If you use the words to someone else's song to make money-- do you have to give the songwriter some of that money?
item.title: #537: Hold The Music, Just The Lyrics Please

item.description: Technology means that no matter what job you have — whether you're alone in a truck on an empty road or sitting in a cubicle in front of a computer — your company can now track everything you do.
item.title: #536: The Future Of Work Looks Like A UPS Truck

item.description: On today's show, we visit a country with almost no government, but a lot of entrepreneurs who have become humanitarians for profit.
item.title: #535: Humanitarians, For A Price

item.description: On today's show: How we got from candles made out of cow fat to as much light as we want. The history of light is the history of economic growth, of things getting faster, cheaper, and more efficient.
item.title: #534: The History of Light

item.description: Lou Caracciolo is trying to make high-quality wine from grapes he grows in New Jersey. But Jersey wine already has a reputation — and fancy isn't it
item.title: #444: New Jersey Wine

item.description: On today's show, we talk to designers and car company executives about one of the biggest technical challenges they face: making all the different governments happy.
item.title: #533: Why Cars From Europe and the US Just Can't Get Along

item.description: Most websites end in .com, .gov or .edu. But a bunch of new domains have just been added. Now there's .ninja, .bike, .plumbing and .cool. In all, over 1,000 new top-level domains will be added.
item.title: #532: The Wild West Of The Internet

item.description: On today's show, we head to some of the cheating-est places on earth to bring you tales from some of the roughest, toughest tax collectors around.
item.title: #531: The Tough, The Sweet And The Nosy

item.description: After today's show, you'll be ready to design a tax on marijuana, pick a law school and discuss the hottest new book in economics (without having to read a page).
item.title: #530: Marijuana, Law School, And Centuries Of Inequality

item.description: People love to complain about their internet service, but most of the time, they can't switch. Today on the show: Why isn't there more competition?
item.title: #529: The Last Mile

item.description: What would the perfect immigration system look like? We asked three economists to dream big.
item.title: #436: If Economists Controlled The Borders

item.description: On today's show: secret deals, Machiavellian negotiation tactics and the minimum wage.
item.title: #528: Money, Work and TV

item.description: Greece, the country we all worried might take down the euro and Europe, may finally be ready to turn around.
item.title: #527: The Amazing Shrinking Economy Might Stop Shrinking

item.description: The US is responding to Russian tanks, artillery and special forces with its own weapon: money.
item.title: #526: A Planet Money War

item.description: Today, we tackle the big question of how to pull an economy out of a recession by going...small.
item.title: #525: Trouble Inside A Babysitting Economy

item.description: Why millions of Americans still haggle with car dealers in person, one brand at a time.
item.title: #435: Why Buying A Car Is So Awful

item.description: There's an obscure law that governs just about anything that travels by ship in the US - bananas, hairdryers, gasoline, even people.
item.title: #524: Me and Mr. Jones

item.description: A grandmother's gas bill can explain a lot about the conflict between Ukraine and Russia.
item.title: #523: The Fight Over Ukraine's Gas Bill

item.description: If you asked someone on the street 100 years ago, "How's the economy doing?" They wouldn't have had any idea what you were talking about.
item.title: #522: The Invention Of 'The Economy'

item.description: In today's episode, we'll take you to a place where dying has become acceptable dinner conversation. A place that also happens to have the lowest healthcare spending of any region in the country.
item.title: #521: The Town That Loves Death

item.description: Duke says it costs $90,000 a year to provide an undergraduate education. The school opens its books and tells us where all that money is going.
item.title: #520: Duke's $30,000 Tuition Discount

item.description: The financial crisis left Wall Street with an image problem. Yet recruits continue to sign up. What's driving today's young bankers and how is that changing?
item.title: #519: Wall Street's Image Problem

item.description: Annoyed? Preoccupied? Great, now donate an organ. How Michigan may have solved a supply problem with one question.
item.title: #518: How To Bore Someone Into Donating An Organ

item.description: It's cheap to fly on Spirit Airlines, but you have to pay extra for perks. And by perks, we mean a bottle of water or space in the overhead bin.
item.title: #517: The Fastest Growing, Least Popular Airline In America

item.description: LeBron James is the most underpaid professional athlete in the world today. On today's show, we explain why that might actually be good for him.
item.title: #427: LeBron James Is Underpaid

item.description: Leaving money on the table. It's a concept economists hate and one that the app Uber is trying to solve. But is this startup really solving a problem by charging you more for your ride to work?
item.title: #516: Why Paying $192 For A 5-Mile Car Ride May Be Rational

item.description: A big-time venture capitalist thinks bitcoin will change the world. A prominent writer thinks bitcoin is going to disappear. On today's show, they make a long-term bet on bitcoin's future.
item.title: #515: A Bet Over Bitcoin

item.description: Tomato inflation in South America. Coal start-ups in Indonesia. Fat Cats on Wall Street. What do they all have to do with each other?
item.title: #514: How Bernanke Set Off Tomato Protests In Brazil

item.description: On today's show, economist and author, Tim Harford, applies economic theory to your questions about love, sex and dating.
item.title: #513: Dear Economist, I Need A Date

item.description: In rural Oaxaca, there are basically no jobs. Two cousins have a dream to change that.
item.title: #512: Can Mezcal Save A Village?

item.description: On today's show: Three stories about people who, intentionally or not, found themselves breaking the rules.
item.title: #511: Rule Breakers

item.description: It's a story of exploding bakeries, a blue eagle, and a guy who may or may not have been drunk.
item.title: #510: The Birth Of The Minimum Wage

item.description: To hire new employees, some companies are paying less attention to resumes and more attention to data — and the data are leading to some surprising findings.
item.title: #509: Will A Computer Decide Whether You Get Your Next Job?

item.description: If you know the right people — and if you can get other criminals to vouch for you — you can go online and buy huge bundles of stolen credit cards. As it turns out, Planet Money knows the right people.
item.title: #282: Inside The Credit Card Black Market

item.description: A famous biologist predicts overpopulation will lead to global catastrophe. An economist disagrees — and challenges the biologist to a very public bet.
item.title: #508: A Bet On The Future Of Humanity

item.description: On today's show, we follow up on a few of the stories we did in 2013.
item.title: #507: The Rest Of The Story

item.description: On today's show: a decades-long feud between two big bell companies, located right down the road from each other.
item.title: #506: Bell Wars

item.description: On today's show, we tell the creation story of the Federal Reserve — one of the most powerful financial institutions on the planet.
item.title: #505: A Locked Door, A Secret Meeting And The Birth Of The Fed

item.description: We sit in on a tense conversation where doctors argue about why it's so hard to start surgery on time. And we hear what happens when you change the way hospitals and doctors get paid.
item.title: #504: Can Hospitals Save Money By Making Doctors Squirm?

item.description: We open up the books and explain how much went to cotton, how much went to workers in Bangladesh, and how much went places we would never have imagined.
item.title: #503: Adding Up The Cost Of The Planet Money T-Shirt

item.description: The U.S. exports over a billion pounds of used clothing every year — and much of that winds up in used clothing markets in sub-Saharan Africa.
item.title: #502: The Afterlife Of A T-Shirt

item.description: On today's show, the Planet Money T-shirts arrive at the Port of Miami. But they're not quite here yet.
item.title: #501: A Shirt, A Meat Grinder And The Book Of Everything

item.description: On today's show: the story of an often-overlooked innovation that's essential to the global economy. The innovation is a box. A big, metal box.
item.title: #500: The Humble Innovation At The Heart Of The Global Economy

item.description: "We asked ourselves, 'What the hell do we want?'" Answer: "We need employment. We need dollars."
item.title: #499: Richard Nixon, Kimchi And The First Clothing Factory In Bangladesh

item.description: In the latest installment of our T-shirt series, we move from Bangladesh to Colombia — and we see an entirely different world.
item.title: #498: The Last T-Shirt In Colombia

item.description: On today's show: the lives of two sisters and the rise of the garment industry in Bangladesh.
item.title: #497: Love, Betrayal And The Planet Money T-Shirt

item.description: After years of planning and months of production, our shirts are here.
item.title: #496: Where The Planet Money T-Shirt Began

item.description: On today's show, we go looking for the people making these loans and find a bizarre online marketplace where people's personal financial information is bought and sold. Plus, we talk to state regulators about why it's so hard to police high interest lending happening online.
item.title: #495: The Weird Inner Workings Of The Payday Loan Business

item.description: A study discovers what happens to farmers in Kenya after they get a windfall. Also: giving money to thieves and drug addicts in a country that's much worse off than Kenya.
item.title: #494: What Happens When You Just Give Money To Poor People?

item.description: Jim Logan did not create the technology to podcast. He himself is not a modern-day podcaster. But he claims to have the patent on podcasting. On today's show, he says all the people out there podcasting today, owe him money.
item.title: #462: When Patents Hit the Podcast

item.description: On today's show, we talk to Eugene Fama and Robert Shiller, who shared this year's economics Nobel. Shiller is a famous explainer of bubbles; Fama is a famous bubble skeptic.
item.title: #493: What's A Bubble? (Nobel Edition)

item.description: Lincolns used to be the coolest cars in the world. On today's show, we hear how Lincoln is trying to regain its former glory.
item.title: #377: Can Lincoln Be Cool Again?

item.description: Michael Erb has reviewed more than 800 products on Amazon — everything from a telescope to facial wipes. Why does he do it?
item.title: #492: M. Erb's Amazon Empire

item.description: It's totally legal. So why do lots of addicts have to buy it on the street?
item.title: #391: The Anti-Addiction Pill That's Big Business For Drug Dealers

item.description: Jane Gleeson-White, author of Double Entry: How the Merchants of Venice Created Modern Finance, tells us the story of how one mathematics book changed business across the planet.
item.title: #407: A Mathematician, The Last Supper And The Birth Of Accounting

item.description: On today's show: Three ripped-from-the-headlines stories from Planet Money.
item.title: #491: The Debt Ceiling, Obamacare And Welfare

item.description: Last year, Americans paid $1.7 billion to play in fantasy sports leagues. Billion!
item.title: #490: The Real Economy Of Fantasy Sports

item.description: And why a photo of steel wool that looks like a tornado costs $1,265.We wade into the economics of the art world.
item.title: #189: Why A Dead Shark Costs $12 Million

item.description: Why does it take so long to send money from one bank account to another?
item.title: #489: The Invisible Plumbing Of Our Economy

item.description: Behind a bucolic dairy farm lies all the roiling tension, rising inequality and economic volatility of the 21st-century economy.
item.title: #352: The High-Tech Cow

item.description: On today's show, we answer the question every cable subscriber has asked: Why can't I just pay for the channels I want?
item.title: #488: The Secret History Of Your Cable Bill

item.description: On today's show, every single dollar bill in the world — every $20, every $100, everything — is printed on paper made at one small mill in Massachusetts. That's been the case for 130 years.
item.title: #371: Where Dollar Bills Come From

item.description: Pretty much everyone who studies poverty agrees: The way the government defines poverty is completely wrong.
item.title: #487: The Trouble With The Poverty Line

item.description: If you're a high school student and you dream of holding the U.S. economy in the palm of your hand — if you want the power to control interest rates and to print money out of thin air — the Fed Challenge is for you.
item.title: #369: If Teens Ran The Fed

item.description: On today's show, we replay key moments from the crisis of 2008. And we ask: Are we safer now than we were five years ago?
item.title: #486: Crisis Revisited

item.description: The most lucrative majors lead to jobs with salaries over $100,000 a year. The least lucrative lead to salaries of around $30,000.
item.title: #485: What's Your Major?

item.description: On today's show, we check in with our team in Bangladesh. We hear what it was like inside the factory where the Planet Money men's T-shirt was knit, dyed, cut and sewn.
item.title: #484: Inside The T-Shirt Factory

item.description: The cotton for the Planet Money men's T-shirt was spun into yarn in Indonesia and knit, cut and sewn into shirts in Bangladesh. On today's show, we hear from Planet Money reporters in both countries.
item.title: #483: Putting The Planet In The Planet Money T-Shirt

item.description: A rainforest in Ecuador sits on top of hundreds of millions of barrels of oil. The government said it would leave the forest untouched — if the world paid up.
item.title: #433: Holding A Rainforest Hostage? (Update)

item.description: Before the Civil War, there were 8,000 different kinds of money in the United States. And a $1 bill wasn't always worth $1.
item.title: #421: The Birth Of The Dollar Bill

item.description: U.S. military aid is unpopular among Egyptians and, increasingly, among U.S. politicians. Yet it hasn't stopped flowing.
item.title: #482: Why The U.S. Keeps Sending Weapons To Egypt

item.description: On today's show, we meet a woman who is trying to bring nuance and subtlety to a world of black-and-white rules: pregnancy.
item.title: #481: The Economist's Guide To Drinking While Pregnant

item.description: GiveDirectly is a charity that just gives money to poor people — no strings attached.
item.title: #480: The Charity That Just Gives People Money

item.description: On today's show, three stories about what how products and people get branded and what happens when you peel back the label and try to get the full story.
item.title: #479: Behind The Label

item.description: Today on the show, raisin farmer, Marvin Horne, is a raisin rebel, a raisin outlaw. He refused to follow the rules of the Raisin Administrative Committee and found himself under surveillance by Rocky Pipkin's detective agency. Now he's being sued by the federal government.
item.title: #478: Rocky Pipkin, Private Eye Vs. The Raisin Outlaw

item.description: More than half of all Japanese women quit their jobs after giving birth to their first child. That's more than double the rate in the U.S., and it's a problem for Japan's economy.
item.title: #477: Waiting For Robot Nannies

item.description: Everybody likes free. But consider a cautionary tale about free doughnuts and the Red Cross.
item.title: #386: The Cost Of Free Doughnuts

item.description: *Not really. But sort of.
item.title: #476: The Return Of The Indicator*

item.description: On today's show, we go see what happened to all the big dreams Detroit has had over the years.
item.title: #475: What Happened To Detroit's Big Plans?

item.description: We got a stack of letters from American citizens who wanted to buy stuff from North Korea. On today's show, we try to figure out who sent the letters, and why.
item.title: #474: The North Korea Files

item.description: On today's show: Everything you need to know about the filibuster.
item.title: #422: Schoolhouse Rock Is A Lie (Or, How The Filibuster Ate Washington)

item.description: How the top three songs in America explain the crazy transformation in the music business.
item.title: #473: Top Of The Charts (Econ Remix)

item.description: Tax carbon emissions. That's basically the whole plan.
item.title: #472: The One-Page Plan To Fix Global Warming

item.description: On today's show, we answer one of the most important questions in finance: What actually happens at the end of Trading Places?
item.title: #471: The Eddie Murphy Rule

item.description: We travel to a place where people are trying to live without government interference. A place where you can use bits of silver to buy uninspected bacon. A place where a a 9-year-old will sell you alcohol.
item.title: #286: Libertarian Summer Camp

item.description: Five years after the financial crisis, the government still controls giant companies that guarantee trillions of dollars in mortgages.
item.title: #470: Killing Fannie Mae

item.description: On today's show: Two stories from Kenya.
item.title: #469: Rhino Horns And Clean Water

item.description: On today's show, we talk to Kid Rock about how he's trying to cut scalpers out of the business — and still sell cheap tickets to his shows.
item.title: #468: Kid Rock Vs. The Scalpers

item.description: How a celebrated attempt to help one group of people ended quietly hurting a much larger group.
item.title: #467: Tires, Taxes And The Grizz

item.description: Mike Smith has thousands of dollars stashed around his house in different accounts. Tamara Bullock is part of an informal savings club. Miguel Rada has a whole bank in his pocket — he takes deposits from some people and lends to others.
item.title: #466: DIY Finance

item.description: Thomas Peterffy's life story includes a typing robot, a proto-iPad, and a vast fortune he amassed as one of the first people to use computers in financial markets.
item.title: #396: A Father Of High-Speed Trading Thinks We Should Slow Down

item.description: On today's show, we meet two businessmen in Yangon. One is launching a startup. The other works for Coca-Cola — which is going back into Myanmar after a 60-year absence.
item.title: #465: Myanmar Opens Up

item.description: *Note: The country is only getting richer on paper, but that change may make a difference in the real world.*
item.title: #464: When A Poor Country Gets A Lot Richer*

item.description: On today's show, how do you get a country to join the world economy when the people there don't even trust their own banks.
item.title: #463: How To Get A Country To Trust Its Banks

item.description: Jim Logan did not create the technology to podcast. He himself is not a modern-day podcaster. But he claims to have the patent on podcasting. On today's show, he says all the people out there podcasting today, owe him money.
item.title: #462: When Patents Hit the Podcast

item.description: On today's show: Three short stories from the far flung shores of New Zealand, Ireland and New Jersey.
item.title: #461: Lawyers, Guns And Money

item.description: Meet a single mother who makes $16,000 a year — and who managed to fund a vacation at a Caribbean resort with an interest-free loan from one of the world's largest banks.
item.title: #217: The Art Of Living At The Poverty Line

item.description: A retired contractor from Colorado has spent the past two years building a school in Haiti. If he had it to do over, he tells us, he might do things differently.
item.title: #460: It's Hard To Do Good

item.description: On today's show: Three short stories about trying to figure out what things are really worth. Also, an update on our t-shirt project.
item.title: #459: Getting It Right

item.description: The Planet Money men's t-shirt will be made in part in Bangladesh.
item.title: #458: Bangladesh's T-Shirt Economy

item.description: On today's show: What the color of the Planet Money t-shirt has to do with a painting from 1969.
item.title: #457: Why Pink?

item.description: Nearly 20 states have legalized marijuana to some degree. As it turns out, this has profound economic consequences for dealers all across the country.
item.title: #456: Marijuana Arbitrage

item.description: Meet a Brazilian who took on the world's largest superpower, a Texas cotton farmer who's tired of hearing the Brazilians complain, and a guy named Renato — a.k.a. Retaliation Master.
item.title: #224: The Cotton Wars

item.description: We're making a t-shirt that tells the story of its own creation.
item.title: #455: The Planet Money T-Shirt Is Finally (Almost) Here

item.description: Sugar costs more in the U.S. than in the rest of the world. If you're in the candy business — if, say, you make 10 million lollipops a day — that's a big deal.
item.title: #454: The Lollipop War

item.description: On today's show we dive deep into the world of correlation and causation with Charles Wheelan, author of the new book, Naked Statistics: Stripping the Dread from the Data.
item.title: #453: What Causes What?

item.description: This week, a grad student found a simple error in one of the most famous economics studies of the past several years. Should this change the way we think about economic research?
item.title: #452: How Much Should We Trust Economics?

item.description: It includes multiple wars, a Supreme Court justice on his deathbed, and Donald Duck.
item.title: #356: The Surprisingly Entertaining History Of The Income Tax

item.description: On today's show, we look at a huge, often overlooked, surprisingly interesting corner of the tax code: The Earned Income Tax Credit.
item.title: #451: Why Some People Love Tax Day

item.description: The value of the virtual currency is skyrocketing. Is that good or bad for bitcoin's future?
item.title: #450: Bitcoin Goes To The Moon

item.description: You can sell an old CD or used record. But what about songs from your iTunes library you no longer want? Or ebooks you've purchased? Do you have the right to resell these digital goods?
item.title: #449: The Hidden Digital Wealth In Your Pocket

item.description: When Hurricane Sandy struck, it devastated businesses all over New York City. One area hit particularly hard was Coney Island. We thought many businesses there were doomed after the storm, but now 5 months later, we return and find things shockingly normal.
item.title: #448: Coney Island Back In Business

item.description: North Korea's exports include illegal drugs, counterfeit U.S. dollars, and giant statues.
item.title: #290: North Korea's Illegal Economy

item.description: How one guy pulled off one of the largest financial scams in Kenyan history, avoided prison, re-branded himself as a man of God, and ran for a seat in parliament.
item.title: #447: The Con Man Who Took Down His Own Country (Then Ran For Office)

item.description: It's come to our attention that we've missed one of the biggest stories in our economy: The startling rise in the number of people on federal disability programs.
item.title: #446: The Invisible 14 Million

item.description: On today's show: Why did the world freak out over the Cyprus bailout?
item.title: #445: Cyprus Takes Away The Security Blanket

item.description: Lou Caracciolo is trying to make high-quality wine from grapes he grows in New Jersey. But Jersey wine already has a reputation — and fancy isn't it.
item.title: #444: New Jersey Wine

item.description: Despite all the celebration, the Dow Jones industrial average has not hit record highs recently. If you adjust for inflation, the highs just aren't as high as they seem. On today's show, we rain on the Dow's parade and explain why a lot of very smart people say we should ignore the Dow.
item.title: #443: Don't Believe The Hype

item.description: Driverless cars! Imported doctors! JC Penney! On today's show, we bring you three stories in one.
item.title: #442: Into The Future

item.description: More Amish are working in business than farming these days. But the Amish lifestyle presents a unique set of business challenges. On today's show, we travel to the The Buckeye Tool Expo to see how the Amish balance their business interests with their personal beliefs.
item.title: #441: Business Secrets Of The Amish

item.description: The new Pope will have to deal with a classic business mess: a multi-billion dollar conglomerate that has stumbled and is losing money and relevance.
item.title: #440: An Economic Makeover For The Catholic Church

item.description: For the uninsured, hospital bills are full of high prices and hard-to-decipher codes.
item.title: #439: The Mysterious Power Of A Hospital Bill

item.description: Two big companies have hatched a plan that could allegedly take money out of the pockets of ordinary Americans. And it's not just any money: it's our beer money.
item.title: #438: Mavericks, Monopolies And Beer

item.description: The uberblogger recently left big media. Will readers' contributions be enough to pay his blog's eight-person staff?
item.title: #437: Can Andrew Sullivan Make It On His Own?

item.description: What would the perfect immigration system look like? We asked three economists to dream big.
item.title: #436: If Economists Controlled The Borders

item.description: Why millions of Americans still haggle with car dealers in person, one brand at a time.
item.title: #435: Why Buying A Car Is So Awful

item.description: Four short stories about how we deal with the threat of danger, death, and crime.
item.title: #434: Dealing With Danger, Death, And Crime

item.description: Ecuador says it will leave its rainforest untouched — if rich countries give Ecuador billions of dollars.
item.title: #433: Holding A Rainforest Hostage?

item.description: On today's show, a years-long, international, multi-billion-dollar battle over one of the most boring things in finance: savings accounts.
item.title: #267: A New Mom And The President of Iceland

item.description: On today's show, we visit a breast pump boutique that has suddenly become a medical supply superstore. And we look at happens when a device goes from being something people have to pay for out of their own pocket to being free for anyone with insurance.
item.title: #432: The Price Of Free Breast Pumps

item.description: If you're looking for the beginning — and, possibly, the end — of the European financial crisis, you can find it in a single building: The Greek statistics office, at 46 Peireos Street in Athens.
item.title: #331: How Office Politics Could Take Down Europe

item.description: The mystery why there was a global rice shortage and ever-increasing prices, all while countries were hoarding rice.
item.title: #320: How Fear Turned A Surplus Into Scarcity

item.description: A hedge-fund manager says a giant company is a fraud. The company fights back. On today's show, we talk to everybody. And we consider what it means when an investor bets that a company will fail.
item.title: #431: A Billion-Dollar Bet Against Weight-Loss Shakes

item.description: On today's show, we learn the surprising truth about what actually happens when you click that link to try and purchase herbal Viagra.
item.title: #430: Black Market Pharmacies And The Spam Empire Behind Them

item.description: On today's show: Three short stories about the stuff we buy — books, toys and clothes.
item.title: #429: The Price Of Things We Love

item.description: Thousands of workers have flooded into the town. But they're reluctant to call it home.
item.title: #428: Turning A Boom Town Into A Real Town

item.description: He makes $17.5 million. He deserves twice that. On today's show, we explain why LeBron is getting hosed — and why that's probably a good thing for NBA fans, team owners, other pro players, and even LeBron himself.
item.title: #427: LeBron James Is Underpaid

item.description: Why they built a three-mile-long bridge when they could have built a much shorter, cheaper bridge nearby.
item.title: #297: A Big Bridge In The Wrong Place

item.description: We look back at the stories we've done in 2012 and tell you how everything turned out.
item.title: #426: 'The Rest Of The Story' (2012 Edition)

item.description: Is there a way to make the holiday season both more efficient and more joyful? On today's Planet Money, we try to answer that question by conducting a wildly unscientific experiment. We go into a seventh-grade classroom and give a bunch of kids some small gifts — candy, raisins, fig newtons.
item.title: #238: Making Christmas More Joyful, And More Efficient

item.description: On today's show, three stories of professional negotiators using negotiation in their everyday lives.
item.title: #425: An FBI Hostage Negotiator Buys A Car

item.description: On today's show, we visit a California county where firefighters asked citizens to support the fire department by paying higher taxes.
item.title: #424: How Much Is A Firefighter Worth?

item.description: On today's show, three stories that aired on the radio but haven't yet made it into the show: Will a $1.9 billion settlement change banks' behavior? Why the falling birthrate is bad news for kids. And the huge pay cut for doctors hiding in the fiscal cliff.
item.title: #423: Just Can't Get Enough

item.description: On today's show: Everything you need to know about the filibuster.
item.title: #422: Schoolhouse Rock Is A Lie (Or, How The Filibuster Ate Washington)

item.description: Before the Civil War, there were 8,000 different kinds of money in the United States. On today's show, we figure out how this world worked. And explain how the war changed everything.
item.title: #421: The Birth Of The Dollar Bill

item.description: On today's show, we discover one big thing that's standing in the way of marijuana entrepreneurs.
item.title: #420: The (Legal) Marijuana Business

item.description: On today's show we go deep into the nature of money itself, and we find a surprisingly clear answer to this question.
item.title: #364: Should We Kill The Dollar Bill?

item.description: On today's show: Four Planet Money stories that aired on the radio but haven't yet made it into the podcast.
item.title: #419: Taylor Swift, Helium, A Jelly-Like Mass and The Price Of Gas

item.description: One day in the early 1990s, a man walked into the U.S. embassy in Ecuador. He said he had information somebody would want to hear — information on how to go after some of the most powerful drug traffickers in the world.
item.title: #418: How The Government Set Up A Fake Bank To Launder Drug Money

item.description: On today's show, we consider a world where everybody cheats and where you can't win unless you game the regulators: Professional cycling.
item.title: #417: Lance Armstrong And The Business Of Doping

item.description: The answer includes a half a million vending machines, a 7.5 cent coin, and a company president who just wanted to get a couple lawyers out of his office.
item.title: #416: Why The Price Of Coke Didn't Change For 70 Years

item.description: On today's show, a North American economist and the chief of staff to a foreign president fall in love with the same idea. It's an idea they think can solve one of the oldest, hardest problems in economics: How can poor countries get richer?
item.title: #415: Can A Poor Country Start Over?

item.description: On today's show, Planet Money stakes out New York City's diamond, plant, and chess districts to answer a nagging question: Why do stores that all sell the same thing set up shop right next to each other?
item.title: #128: Friend or Foe?

item.description: On today's show, a flooded grocery store reveals backup plans that are usually hidden but, at moments like these, are suddenly made visible.
item.title: #414: After The Flood, The Backup Plan

item.description: You rarely see lard on menus. There aren't shelves and shelves of it in every supermarket. In this country, we've sort of lost touch with the once beloved pig fat. On today's podcast, we ask — who killed lard?
item.title: #335: Who Killed Lard?

item.description: On today's show, Planet Money's economist-approved fake candidate (sort of) goes to a focus group, and creates his first ads.
item.title: #413: Our Fake Candidate Meets The People

item.description: On today's show, we talk with a Stanford law professor about the problems with software patents — and how to fix the system.
item.title: #412: How To Fix The Patent Mess

item.description: A robber baron who spent his billions on finger paint and changing tables. Decades-long studies that found preschool made a huge difference in the lives of poor children. And a Nobel prize-winning economist.
item.title: #411: Why Preschool Can Save The World

item.description: America still makes the world's most popular music. But other countries are fighting for their share of the global market. In other worlds: Gangnam Style is not a fluke.
item.title: #410: Why K-Pop Is Taking Over The World

item.description: On today's show, we follow up with Willow Tufano. She just bought another house. She's trying to land a reality TV deal. And she recently wore a Pikachu costume on a trip to Alabama.
item.title: #409: The 15-Year-Old Who Bought Two Houses

item.description: We set up two shell companies. Now we have to figure out what to do with them.
item.title: #408: How To Hide Money From Your Spouse

item.description: Lots of economists write about illegal drugs. One thing missing from their papers: Actual drug dealers.
item.title: #266: A Former Crack Dealer On The Economics Of Drugs

item.description: Jane Gleeson-White, author of Double Entry: How the Merchants of Venice Created Modern Finance, tells us the story of how one mathematics book changed business across the planet.
item.title: #407: A Mathematician, The Last Supper And The Birth Of Accounting

item.description: We bring in real political consultants to help us plan a campaign for our fake candidate. Our goal: Sell our candidate to America by making economics sexy.

item.description: Global trade wars. Small-time bike thieves. And what happens when the Fed talks big. On today's show, we bring you three short Planet Money stories.
item.title: #405: Cheating, Stealing And Quantitative Easing

item.description: Fixing the economy is tough — even if you can change anything you want.
item.title: #404: What If You Controlled The Economy?

item.description: And how can we meet our fake shareholder and fake director?
item.title: #403: What Can We Do With Our Shell Companies?

item.description: A new tax on financial speculation. Two trillion dollars in new deficit spending. Free heroin for addicts. And other pet ideas from our panel of economists
item.title: #402: Free Heroin, And Other Ideas That Won't Get You Elected

item.description: On today's show, we have four short Planet Money stories.

item.description: Italy is two countries — and two economies — in one.

item.description: Hanging out with meat inventors, cutting up chickens, and thinking about patents and innovation.
item.title: #399: Can You Patent A Steak?

item.description: On today's show, we talk to Nicholas Wapshott, author of Keynes Hayek: The Clash That Defined Modern Economics.
item.title: #398: Obama, Ryan And Two Dead Economists

item.description: The city of Harrisburg, Pa is $1.5 billion in debt. The man who once was in charge of the saving the city explains how it went so wrong and why it's so hard to fix it.
item.title: #397: Why The Hero Of Harrisburg Couldn't Save The City

item.description: Thomas Peterffy's life story includes a typing robot, a proto-iPad, and a vast fortune he amassed as one of the first people to use computers in financial markets.

item.description: On today's show: Cross-border tensions in the home of the euro.
item.title: #395: Maastricht, Marijuana And The European Dream

item.description: On today's show, we travel to Fairbury, Illinois. We meet three generations of farmers who tell us that, even without crop insurance, their farms would survive the drought.

item.description: An office building on the Dutch-German border was supposed to make it easy to work in both countries. But it's also a reminder of how the European dream isn't yet a reality.

item.description: On today's Planet Money: The legend of the national debt. Where the debt came from, what happened the one time we paid it all off, and who came up with the whole debt-ceiling idea in the first place.

item.description: How the federal agency that compiles the monthly jobs report makes sure it doesn't leak.

item.description: It's totally legal. So why do lots of addicts have to buy it on the street?

item.description: On today's show, we dive deep into the world of offshore companies and bank accounts.We set up our own company in an offshore tax haven, and we find out where the easiest place to hide your money is.

item.description: We revisit three radio pieces, on how blind trusts work, how the European Central Bank has been flexing its muscle, and why public pension plans are about to look less healthy.

item.description: It's tough to figure out how big price-tags really are when they're far in the future. But getting it wrong can have serious consequences.

item.description: On today's show: The Planet Money economic platform. Backed by the brightest minds in modern economics. Pure poison to any politician that embraces it.

item.description: Everybody likes free, and the Internet is bursting with free services. But as companies try to figure out how to make money, consider a cautionary tale about free doughnuts and the Red Cross.

item.description: As citizens lose trust in their lawmakers, they jockey for special treatment — and often get it. That just compounds the problem, argues University of Chicago economist Luigi Zingales.

item.description: It's really, really hard to create the right kind of economic incentives — even if you're a professional economist, and all you're trying to do is teach your kids to use the toilet.

item.description: The most important interest rate in the world has been set by what amounts to an honor system among banks. Now it turns out at least one bank was fudging the numbers.

item.description: The Supreme Court's decision will change peoples' lives. On today's show, we talk to a few of those people.

item.description: Going public doesn't hold the same allure it once did for many entrepreneurs
item.title: #382: The Cool Kids Don't Want To Go Public

item.description: Licensing laws are supposed to protect the public. But they also raise prices and make it harder for people to find work.

item.description: Does Greece have any alternatives to austerity?

item.description: On today's show, we talk to a Harvard economist who answers a surprisingly contentious question.

item.description: A group of people tried to fix a problem, but wound up creating a banking monster.
item.title: #378: How Spain Created A Banking Monster

item.description: Lincolns used to be the coolest cars in the world. On today's show, we hear how Lincoln is trying to regain its former glory.

item.description: On today's show, we walk through the three things you can do to stop a bank run — and figure out what options are left for Europe.

item.description: Here's what happened when a European currency union broke up after World War I.
item.title: #321: Kill The Euro, Win $400,000

item.description: States have promised their employees sweet retirement benefits, but haven't set aside enough money. Now, one public pension fund has filed for bankruptcy.

item.description: The answer has to do with history, politics, and a growing class of entrepreneurs who are struggling to pick a side.
item.title: #374: Why Is Syria Locked In Endless Conflict?

item.description: On Friday, Facebook was valued at over $100 billion. But will the company grow into its promise? And how might it happen?

item.description: Unlike many scarce resources, lungs aren't for sale. So doctors have had to figure out how to allocate them.

item.description: Every single dollar bill in the world — every $20, every $100, everything — is printed on paper made at one small mill in Massachusetts. That's been the case for 130 years.

item.description: There's a huge gap between the sticker price for college tuition and the price students actually pay. On today's show, we try to figure out why.

item.description: If you're a high school student and you dream of holding the U.S. economy in the palm of your hand — if you want the power to control interest rates and to print money out of thin air — the Fed Challenge is for you.

item.description: On today's show, we take a world tour with Ian Bremmer to find out who thrives and who struggles in a world where no one's in charge.

item.description: On today's show, we bring you three Planet Money radio stories.

item.description: On today's show, the key to succeeding in the food truck business: the perfect parking spot.

item.description: Taxes are set to go up for most Americans next year. That's a good thing, Simon Johnson argues.

item.description: Should we kill the dollar bill? On today's show we go deep into the nature of money itself, and we find a clear answer to this question.

item.description: We talk to a guy who started out as an upstanding businessman, and went on to commit bank fraud involving millions of dollars.

item.description: Does it make sense for a country the size of Staten Island to have its own currency? Iceland wants to know.

item.description: How do you make money manufacturing a dry, bland cracker that a tiny percentage of the population eats just one week a year?
item.title: #361: The Matzo Economy

item.description: On today's show, we eat artisanal beef jerky, watch Nancy Pelosi raise money, and meet high priced nannies. It's is a collection of our recent radio stories.

item.description: David Unkovic is a thoughtful, mild-mannered guy who was appointed to save Harrisburg, Pa. Then he disappeared.
item.title: #359: This Man Tried To Save A Broke City

item.description: On today's show, we reveal which Congressional committees are a fundraising goldmine. And which committees actually make it harder for Congressmen to raise money.

item.description: Guilds set up a system of fines, wage ceilings, and public rebukes that would be the envy of a modern cartel.

item.description: It includes multiple wars, a Supreme Court justice on his deathbed, and Donald Duck.

item.description: When a 14-year-old girl can buy a house for $12,000, is it a sign the market has bottomed?

item.description: A former employee describes what life was like inside a giant mortgage lender back in 2006. It's not pretty.

item.description: Has China built too much stuff with borrowed money?

item.description: What should the government pay for? We put the question to an economist.
item.title: #227: Lighthouses, Autopsies And The Federal Budget

item.description: Oreos in China. A van-based visa business. A stock index. And a way to save Greece.

item.description: A Stanford finance professor tells us what she thinks is wrong with banking — and how we can fix it.
item.title: #344: Can We Create Banks We Love?

item.description: An economist presents the case against hosting the Super Bowl. Bonus: today's show is co-hosted by NPR's Mike Pesca.

item.description: Instapaper is a little app that started out as a side project. Now it's a thriving one-man business. We talk to Marco Arment, Instapaper's founder and sole employee, about the app economy.
item.title: #342: The App Economy

item.description: On the podcast today, we get a glimpse from inside the room where money changes hands. Jimmy Williams used to lobby for the National Association of Realtors. He tells us about the ridiculous issues he's lobbied for, the flow of campaign money he supplied, and how he wants to change the system now.
item.title: #341: A Former Lobbyist Tells All

item.description: We found a guy — a hedge fund manager who bought Greek bonds. He explains why working out a deal on Greek debt is so complicated.

item.description: How much did Katy Perry's label spend on her album? And how much did they make?

item.description: We talk to an economist — and hear a first-hand account of what life is like under sanctions.
item.title: #338: Do Sanctions Work?

item.description: In 1978, a group of farmers in a Chinese village called Xiaogang wrote a secret contract and hid it in the roof of a mud hut. They were afraid the document might get them executed. Instead, it wound up completely transforming the Chinese economy.
item.title: #337: The Secret Document That Transformed China

item.description: Today on the podcast, we're going to take a trip to Greenville, South Carolina, where factories filled with bright shiny machines sit just across the train tracks from shuttered old mills. It's the perfect place to ask the question — what is the state of the low skilled American worker?
item.title: #336: The Past And Future Of American Manufacturing

item.description: You rarely see lard on menus. There aren't shelves and shelves of it in every supermarket. In this country, we've sort of lost touch with the once beloved pig fat. On today's podcast, we ask — who killed lard?
item.title: #335: Who Killed Lard?

item.description: On today's show, we visit a few people who have been doing well. There's a guy with a gold vault. A company that sells off inventories for bankrupt stores. And the king of coconut water.

item.description: We look back at the podcasts we've done in 2011 and tell you what we got right, what we got wrong and how everything turned out in Wisconsin and Iceland. Plus, we try to to figure out why that Rihanna song that cost so much money, bombed on the radio.

item.description: And how seventh graders solved the problem.
item.title: #238: Making Christmas More Joyful, And More Efficient

item.description: Or: Why a mild-mannered technocrat faces life in prison.
item.title: #331: How Office Politics Could Take Down Europe

item.description: Earlier this year we reported on the pileup of more than a billion unwanted $1 coins in government vaults. It was the result of a law passed a few years back that ordered the mint to create coins honoring each U.S. president.Today, the White House said it will end the program.

item.description: On today's podcast, we try to answer the question — why do airlines keep going bankrupt?
item.title: #329: The 'Nasty, Rotten' Airline Business

item.description: On today's show, we go shopping. We're bringing you stories about how we spend our money and what these purchases teach us about economics.

item.description: Last month in New York City, two taxi medallions, the metal plates that make it legal to dive a cab in the city, sold for $1 million each. On today's show, we find out why these little pieces of metal are worth so much.

item.description: The mystery why there was a global rice shortage and ever-increasing prices, all while countries were hoarding rice.
