item.description: On today's show, we go inside the rooms in Washington where the daily grind of campaign finance — Congressmen, lobbyists, money — takes place. At least, we try to go inside the rooms.
item.title: #319: Inside Washington's Money Machine

item.description: We talk with Nicholas Wapshott, the author of the new book Keynes Hayek: The Clash That Defined Modern Economics. The fight over their ideas has never been more relevant.
item.title: #318: Keynes Vs. Hayek

item.description: Economists love economic growth. And economic news — on Planet Money and elsewhere — presents growth as a good thing. But on today's show, we ask: Is economic growth bad for the planet?
item.title: #317: Will Economic Growth Destroy The Planet?

item.description: We got our hands on a secret government report outlining what once looked like a potential crisis: The possibility that the U.S. government might pay off its entire debt.
item.title: #316: What If We Paid Off The Debt?

item.description: Germany and France are tied together by fate. On today's show, the story of France and Germany — the relationship on which the fate of Europe depends.
item.title: #315: France And Germany, A Love Story

item.description: It seems unlikely that Greece will be able to avoid defaulting on its loans. The real question is how the default will happen — will it be clean and organized or messy and catastrophic.The nightmare scenario Greece most wants to avoid is what happened in Argentina.
item.title: #314: The Price Of Default

item.description: We talk with Daniel Yergin, author of a new book called The Quest. The book's heroes are the engineers and scientists of the energy world.
item.title: #313: The Future Of Energy

item.description: It's not a movement; it's a venue. And there's an economist who thinks it can be a model for the whole country.
item.title: #312: What Is Occupy Wall Street?

item.description: On today's show, we visit a place where global economic forces converge: Colo, Iowa. The price of farmland in Iowa has doubled in the past few years. We look at the broader economic picture, and ask: Is it a bubble?
item.title: #311: The Land Boom

item.description: An airline, the price of oil and the financialization of the global economy. On today's show, author and former banker Satyajit Das talks about his career and the trouble with the rise of finance.
item.title: #310: How Money Got Weird

item.description: For today's show, we collected four Planet Money radio stories that never made it to the podcast.
item.title: #309: Four In One

item.description: "We need Greece, we need Spain, we need Italy," a cab driver told us. "It's the ending of war and it's the beginning of a new future. It's the dream for European peoples."
item.title: #308: The Dream Of Europe And The Bailout Of Greece

item.description: Planet Money's pet toxic asset, died last year. But we learned recently that she may rise from the grave.
item.title: #307: Toxie's Back!

item.description: The unemployment rate in Germany is just 6 percent — and it's declining. We spent a week in Germany learning their secret recipe.
item.title: #306: Germany's Painful Solution To High Unemployment

item.description: The debt-ceiling debate was a game of chicken, a political scientist says. And the supercommittee may actually work out a deal.
item.title: #305: When Congress Plays Chicken

item.description: An economic disaster from 90 years ago may determine the fate of Europe's economy.
item.title: #304: The Ghost That Haunts Europe's Debt Crisis

item.description: A financial crisis that began with the popping of a huge housing bubble and led to a stock market plunge and a banking crisis? That's right: We're talking about Japan in the 1990s.
item.title: #1: Japan's Lost Lesson

item.description: What's the worst that could happen? Bank runs, political riots and falling governments, for a start. Also, the end of the euro as we know it.
item.title: #303: Europe's Worst-Case Scenario

item.description: Europe is borrowing money to bail out countries that got in trouble by borrowing too much money.
item.title: #302: To Solve Debt Problem, Europe Borrows More Money

item.description: With Moammar Gadhafi on the run, Libya needs to start thinking about its next big challenge — what to do with the massive amount of wealth they as a country possess in oil. Almost all countries that find oil suffer from the resource curse. But there is one notable exception — Norway.
item.title: #301: Norway Has Advice For Libya

item.description: Today on the podcast, we talk to some close observers of the hacker group Anonymous to find out how they operate and what they want.
item.title: #300: Pizzas, Faxes And Robot Networks

item.description: "The Swiss dream of isolating themselves from trouble is just an impossible dream."
item.title: #299: Switzerland's Too Strong For Its Own Good

item.description: Despite the euro's troubles, Estonia's still doing well. It has the highest growth rate and the lowest public debt of any EU country.On today's podcast, we talk to Estonia's president.
item.title: #244: The Euro's Model Student

item.description: The global popularity of the dollar provides huge benefits for the U.S. But in the coming years, other currencies may challenge the dollar's dominance.
item.title: #298: Why The World Still Needs Dollars

item.description: Why did they build a three-mile-long bridge when they could have built a much shorter, cheaper bridge nearby?
item.title: #297: A Big Bridge In The Wrong Place

item.description: "It's tough to be the Italian house in the deteriorating European neighborhood," PIMCO's head of European portfolio management tells us.
item.title: #296: Italy's A Nice Place, But The Neighborhood's Going Downhill

item.description: Patents are supposed to promote innovation. But in the world of software and the Internet, they're having precisely the opposite effect.
item.title: #295: The Patent War

item.description: Today's podcast is a recording of the live show Alex and Adam did in DC this week. In keeping with the vibe of the nation's capital, they talk a lot about America.
item.title: #294: Planet Money Live

item.description: One expert tells us a downgrade of America's credit rating might not be that big of a deal.
item.title: #293: Would A Downgrade Matter?

item.description: We talk to travelers who use frequent-flier-mile credit cards to buy dollar coins and pile up miles. And we hear how the U.S. Mint is cracking down.
item.title: #292: Dollar Coins In The Wild

item.description: On today's Planet Money, we put that question to Harvard economist Ken Rogoff. We talk to Rogoff about three countries in particular: Greece, Italy and the U.S.
item.title: #291: How Much Debt Is Too Much?

item.description: North Korea's exports include illegal drugs, counterfeit U.S. dollars and giant statues.
item.title: #290: North Korea's Illegal Economy

item.description: On today's Planet Money, we look at a new kind of currency that's not backed by any government.
item.title: #289: Bitcoin

item.description: On today's show, we tell the story of a secret battle that's been going on for more than a year: The fight to create the song of the summer, the music industry's holy grail.
item.title: #288: Manufacturing The Song Of The Summer

item.description: The family behind Crazy Eddie, the electronics store, ran a massive fraud for years. Eddie's cousin Sam Antar, tells us how they did it and why it worked for so long.
item.title: #82: Inside The Mind Of A Financial Criminal

item.description: Thomas Hoenig thinks the Fed is repeating mistakes of the past, keeping interest rates too low for too long. That risks creating another bubble, and another crash, he says.
item.title: #287: Fed Behaving Dangerously, Fed President Says

item.description: We travel to a place where people are trying to live without government interference. A place where you can use bits of silver to buy uninspected bacon. A place where a a 9-year-old will sell you alcohol.
item.title: #286: Libertarian Summer Camp

item.description: On today's Planet Money, we visit an underground vault that's full of money nobody wants.
item.title: #285: Wasting Money Making Money

item.description: Unemployment is still dangerously high but things are looking better for both households and companies, says economist Mark Zandi.
item.title: #284: When Will The Economy Get Better?

item.description: According to one theory, we tip because we feel guilty.
item.title: #283: Why Do We Tip?

item.description: If you know the right people — and if you can get other criminals to vouch for you — you can go online and buy huge bundles of stolen credit cards. As it turns out, Planet Money knows the right people.
item.title: #282: Inside The Credit Card Black Market

item.description: Paying for poor kids to go to preschool saves the government money in the long run, an economist argues.
item.title: #281: The Case For Preschool

item.description: We talk to a pair of MIT economists who do real-world experiments. Their goal: Figure out the best ways to fight global poverty.
item.title: #280: Poor Economics

item.description: On today's Planet Money, we hit the streets with economist Tim Harford. In his new book, Adapt, Harford argues that success always starts with failure.
item.title: #279: The Failure Tour Of New York

item.description: "We will have to share power with a whole lot of others," he says. "We will have to recognize that we can't set the standards, we can't set the agenda, we can't set the rules."
item.title: #278: Fareed Zakaria's Post-American World

item.description: How do you figure out whether the governor created a job, or whether it would have been created without him?
item.title: #277: How Many Jobs Has Scott Walker Created?

item.description: On today's Planet Money, we take a big-picture look at the International Monetary Fund. Our guest is Simon Johnson, who was the IMF's chief economist in 2007 and 2008.
item.title: #276: Do We Need The IMF?

item.description: Jonathan Coulton makes a lot of money selling his music on the Internet. Is he a new model for musicians, or a lucky fluke?
item.title: #275: Is This Man A Snuggie?

item.description: On today's show, we sell our gold coin. We find out whether we made or lost money — and try to figure out whether we're in a gold bubble.
item.title: #274: We Sold Gold

item.description: On today's Planet Money: The legend of the national debt. Where the debt came from, what happened the one time we paid it all off, and who came up with the whole debt-ceiling idea in the first place.
item.title: #273: When The U.S. Paid Off The Entire National Debt

item.description: Ali Tarhouni fled Libya 40 years ago and wound up teaching microeconomics at the University of Washington. Now, he's back in Libya — working as the rebels' finance minister
item.title: #272: The Finance Minister Who Robbed A Bank

item.description: Knights are extortionists. Guilds knock down your house if you don't play by their rules. And you have to wait until the black death kills a third of Europe before anything changes.
item.title: #72: Bloody, Miserable Medieval Economics

item.description: There was a brief moment — post-Friendster, pre-Facebook — when MySpace was a big deal. How did that happen? And why was the moment so brief? The answer involves porn, spyware, and total ignorance.
item.title: #84: MySpace Was Born Of Total Ignorance. Also Porn And Spyware

item.description: How did a barren, icy island become a thriving, modern economy?
item.title: #271: A City On The Moon

item.description: Our long-running story about a school in Haiti continues. Also: A decade of U.S. home prices, sung as opera.
item.title: #270: How To Build A School In Haiti

item.description: The question is being debated in state capitals around the country. But when you look at the data, the answer is clear.
item.title: #269: Do The Rich Flee High-Tax States?

item.description: During the boom, Iceland's banks got rich by going abroad. When the crisis hit, that led to a big problem.
item.title: #268: The Island That Ran Out Of Money

item.description: The Planet Money team heads for Iceland. We get there just before the big election, when the people will vote decide whether to pick up the tab for mistakes bankers made before the financial crisis.
item.title: #267: A New Mom, Bjork's Dad And The President Of Iceland

item.description: Lots of economists write about illegal drugs. One thing missing from their papers: Actual drug dealers.
item.title: #266: A Former Crack Dealer On The Economics Of Drugs

item.description: An entire show about coupons, Groupons, and the economic history of cheapskates.
item.title: #265: Groupon! Monty Python! Price Discrimination!

item.description: Every politician promises to create jobs. On today's Planet Money, we ask: What does that mean?
item.title: #264: How Do You Create A Job?

item.description: Should taxpayers be on the hook when people take out mortgages and don't pay them back?
item.title: #263: What Comes After Fannie And Freddie?

item.description: They're two of the strangest companies in U.S. history — and their bailouts cost taxpayers more than the bailouts of AIG, GM, Citigroup, Bank of America and Goldman Sachs combined.
item.title: #262: Fannie And Freddie's Rise And Fall

item.description: Should NPR receive federal funding? On today's Planet Money, we try to look at the question through the cold, hard lens of economics.
item.title: #261: Economists On Federal Funding For NPR

item.description: The crisis in Japan is a horrible human tragedy. On today's Planet Money we ask: Is it also an economic disaster?
item.title: #260: Why Japan Will Bounce Back

item.description: We read the thing you've never read: Your credit card agreement. And we pose the question: Does it really have to be so long and complicated?
item.title: #259: 4th Graders Read A Credit Card Agreement

item.description: We look at the world through the eyes of Matt LeBlanc, an efficiency expert (or lean expert), who runs around with a stopwatch and equations, trying to figure out how to eliminate waste in our economy. He finds it everywhere.
item.title: #150: Our Messy, Inefficient Economy

item.description: In China's latest five-year plan, the government says it wants less economic growth — and a greater focus on inequality and environmental problems.
item.title: #258: China's Growth Problem

item.description: An economist answers a timeless question.
item.title: #257: Money Buys Happiness

item.description: When borrowers don't pay, should the bank take everything? We look at different answers to the question.
item.title: #256: Discipline And Forgiveness

item.description: In Egypt, the people are the military's customers. In Libya, the military doesn't need the people.
item.title: #255: The Difference Between Egypt And Libya

item.description: On today's Planet Money, we hear the words of ordinary man trying to come to grips with the Great Depression.
item.title: #254: Inside The Great Depression

item.description: On today's Planet Money: The gold standard and the Great Depression. It's the latest in our gold series.
item.title: #253: Gold Standard, R.I.P.

item.description: We visit the charming curmudgeon and respected finance writer James Grant. He says we should go back on the gold standard.
item.title: #252: The Gold Standard

item.description: "At bottom, I'm not all that interested in money," Lewis tells us.
item.title: #251: Michael Lewis, Financial Disaster Travel Journalist

item.description: As regulators write the new finance rules, we sit in on a book club and visit a public hearing full of finance-industry people.
item.title: #250: Writing The Rules

item.description: We look at the Egyptian military's deep business ties to everything from dishwashers to resort hotels. And we consider how those ties influence the military's actions in the crisis.
item.title: #249: Egypt's Military, Inc.

item.description: We talk with Nicholas Phillipson, the author of a new biography of Adam Smith. Besides learning about the intellectual and political world Smith inhabited, we hear a bit about the man himself.
item.title: #248: Adam Smith, Mama's Boy

item.description: The members of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission agreed on an awful lot. But they couldn't agree on the moral of the story.
item.title: #247: The Moral Of The Financial Crisis

item.description: A new study suggests that replacing the weakest 5 to 8 percent of teachers could add $100 trillion to the U.S. economy, over 80 years. We talk to the man behind the research, economist Eric Hanushek.
item.title: #246: How Much Is A Good Teacher Worth?

item.description: On today's podcast, we consult with trade lawyer Michael Cone about where to make our t-shirt, and visit the lab where customs officials check to make sure importers are following the rules.
item.title: #245: A Meat Grinder For Fabric

item.description: On today's show, we bring you the story of one country that played by the rules and did everything exactly the way they were supposed to. One country that worked tirelessly to gain access to the special club of the euro — Estonia.
item.title: #244: The Euro's Model Student

item.description: The 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage -- the bedrock of American home ownership -- is a really weird loan.
item.title: #243: The Frankenstein Mortgage

item.description: Last month, we asked you to participate in our economics experiment. On today's podcast, we dive into the results — and explain what they say about the stock market.
item.title: #242: Our Cute Animal Experiment, Explained

item.description: We're living in a world where there's no clear economic leadership. That creates a new set of problems.
item.title: #241: G-Zero

item.description: Meet Angel Borges, matchmaker for Spain's troubled banks. He's playing a key role in Spain's plan to merge sick banks with healthy ones.
item.title: #240: Marrying Off Spain's Troubled Banks

item.description: The fate of Spain's economy may lie in a couple dozen savings banks called cajas de ahorros. These banks hold more than 50 percent of Spanish bank deposits and many are in danger of failing.
item.title: #239: The Wednesday Podcast: Tiny Banks, Big Problems

item.description: Gift-giving makes economists crazy. It's so inefficient!
item.title: #238: Making Christmas More Joyful, And More Efficient

item.description: Economists love to point out that the simplest products -- a pencil, say, or a cup of cappuccino -- are the results of an incredibly complex system.
item.title: #237: Cappuccino Reconsidered

item.description: Today on the podcast, why a horrible economy can be really good for pursuing your dreams.
item.title: #236: The Economics of Pursuing Your Dreams

item.description: A stone coin that weighs more than a small car says a lot about the meaning of money. The latest story in our gold series.
item.title: #235: A Giant Stone Coin At The Bottom Of The Sea

item.description: The world's biggest economies spend a summer plotting in secret, over French wine, to make the dollar worth much, much less.
item.title: #234: Wine, Cigars, And The Plan To Fix The Dollar

item.description: Europe is borrowing money to bail out countries that got in trouble by borrowing too much money.
item.title: #233: Is Europe's Bailout A Giant Shell Game?

item.description: The principal of a rural school dreamed of a new schoolhouse. It didn't work out so well.
item.title: #232: What Your $3,000 Bought In Haiti

item.description: On today's Planet Money, we hear the story of how Ireland's decision to bail out its banks also had huge consequences for Europe and the U.S.
item.title: #231: Too Big To Save

item.description: Okay we admit it, we stole our idea to make a t-shirt and report every part of the process from Pietra Rivoli, who wrote the book, The Travels of a T-shirt in a Global Economy.
item.title: #230: Pietra Rivoli's T-Shirt Travels

item.description: What could take the place of gold? A professor of chemical engineering walks us through the periodic table of the elements.
item.title: #229: Why Gold?

item.description: There's an argument about whether or not the $2.5 trillion in the Social Security trust funds exists or not, and it centers around the use of the term "trust fund."
item.title: #228: In Search Of The Social Security Trust Funds

item.description: What should the government pay for? On today's Planet Money, we pose that question to Charlie Wheelan, author of the book Naked Economics, and recent Congressional candidate.
item.title: #227: Lighthouses, Autopsies And The Federal Budget

item.description: We've been waiting for two years to get an apology from someone who played a part in this financial crisis. Finally, it's here.
item.title: #226: Finally, An Apology

item.description: Mark Zandi tells us what it will take for the bust to end -- and sketches out housing's profound influence on the broader economy.
item.title: #225: The End Of The Housing Bust

item.description: We go to Texas and Brazil in search of cotton for the Planet Money t-shirt. We find a long-running trade war.
item.title: #224: The Cotton Wars

item.description: It turns out it's really hard for a small team of public radio employees to turn themselves into a cutting-edge apparel company.
item.title: #223: Stealing Our Way To A T-Shirt

item.description: And what it has to do with how big your raise is next year.
item.title: #222: The Price Of Lettuce In Brooklyn

item.description: How does a guy whose mom is a heroin addict — a guy who drops out of high school, has a kid, and starts working a minimum-wage job at a fast-food restaurant — climb out of poverty?
item.title: #221: When A Dead-End Job Isn't A Dead End

item.description: We buy gold — and find that it raises some unsettling questions. Why is our little gold coin worth $419? You can't eat it. You can't fuel your car with it. And three years ago, it was worth half as much.
item.title: #220: Gold!

item.description: Do you want a mansion and servants, or antibiotics and air conditioning?
item.title: #219: Would You Rather Be Rich In 1900, Or Middle-Class Now?

item.description: The U.S. is the world's biggest manufacturer -- way bigger than China. So why doesn't it feel that way?
item.title: #218: Buttons And Other Connectors

item.description: Meet a single mother who makes $16,000 a year — and who managed to fund a vacation at a Caribbean resort with an interest-free loan from one of the world's largest banks.
item.title: #217: The Art Of Living At The Poverty Line

item.description: Their solution for Brazil's chronic inflation: Create a currency that doesn't exist.
item.title: #216: How Four Drinking Buddies Saved Brazil

item.description: Say you want to make loans to millions of very poor women in the developing world, to help them climb out of poverty. Is it OK to raise money from rich investors, who expect to make a profit?
item.title: #215: What's Better For Helping The Poor — Greed Or Charity?

item.description: We are gathered here to day to commemorate the passing of Toxie, Planet Money's toxic asset.
item.title: #214: Toxie, R.I.P.

item.description: People could be richer, better-looking, and thinner under a libertarian government — according to a libertarian.
item.title: #213: Better Living Through Libertarianism

item.description: Everybody's throwing those words around these days. But what do they really mean?
item.title: #212: We Found A Socialist!

item.description: We talk to a woman who bought a house during the boom — and whose mortgage wound up in our toxic asset. Can you ever spot a bubble before it bursts?
item.title: #211: The Origin Of Toxie

item.description: Deadly sea captains! Rampant pollution! And other stories economists tell on the first day of class.
item.title: #210: Summer's Over, Slackers. Back To School.

item.description: Satyajit Das, a risk consultant, who wrote the book Traders, Guns & Money, says the global financial crisis gave legislators and regulators an opportunity to address speculative activity in the deriatives market, but they missed it.
item.title: Deep Read: 'Traders, Guns, And Money'

item.description: On today's Planet Money, listeners suggest ways to cut the federal budget -- and experts evaluate their suggestions.
item.title: #209: Our Listeners Vs. The Budget Deficit

item.description: We go inside the Fed to find out how the central bank bought $1.25 trillion of mortgage bonds.
item.title: #208: How To Spend $1,249,999,999,999.39

item.description: In the last days of the housing boom, some bankers knew there were serious problems in the mortgage market. But rather than wind their business down, they sped it up.
item.title: #207: Wall Street Trickery Inflated The Bubble

item.description: The safety of the global financial system depends in large part on what regulators decide in round, windowless rooms in a tower in Basel, Switzerland.
item.title: #206: Round Room, No Windows

item.description: It's really, really hard to create the right kind of economic incentives — even if you're a professional economist, and all you're trying to do is teach your kids to use the toilet.
item.title: #205: Allowance, Taxes And Potty Training

item.description: On today's Planet Money, we leap 30 years into the future -- when China's economy is bigger than America's.
item.title: #204: We're Number Two!

item.description: Since its creation the internet has been a kind of economists dream; a place without barriers, where any idea can get a hearing, where the best ideas win. But some worry the dream could be ending.
item.title: #203: Creating Lanes On The Information Superhighway

item.description: Has the $787 billion stimulus package saved our economy?
item.title: #202: The Great Stimulus Experiment

item.description: On today's podcast, we pit economists Daniel Hamermesh and Russ Roberts against our own Alex Blumberg and Robert Smith in a heavily edited game of Monopoly to find out what economic lessons the game has to offer.
item.title: #201: Monopoly, A Dangerous Game?

item.description: On today's podcast we explain how Prohibition, a divisive moral issue, became a celebrated business stimulus plan.
item.title: #200: The Moonshine Stimulus

item.description: Today on the podcast, we come up with 5 different ways to put a pricetag on a pelican.
item.title: #199: Tallying Up The Pelican Bill

item.description: A home inside Toxie, our toxic asset, is part of a $200 million mortgage scheme.
item.title: #198: Toxie's Dark Past

item.description: We go on the road to Florida to learn more about the people behind Toxie, Planet Money's toxic asset.
item.title: #197: We Take Toxie On The Road

item.description: A 62-year-old grandmother and her 18-year-old grandson have a fake job interview with Planet Money.
item.title: #196: Grandmother vs. Grandson, Steel-Cage Match

item.description: An industry study found smokers save society money — in part because they tend to die young.
item.title: #195: Death Saves You Money

item.description: We talk to Barney Frank, the Democratic congressman, about key questions the finance bill leaves unanswered.
item.title: #194: What The Finance Bill Doesn't Tell Us

item.description: The criminal underworld, the nature of human happiness, and the economics of LeBron James.
item.title: #193: LeBronomics

item.description: Meet Jonathan Bush: former ambulance driver, cousin of George W. Bush, and the CEO of athenahealth, a public company that doctors pay to manage their billing.
item.title: #192: The Pain-In-The-Butt Index

item.description: A shopkeeper left destitute by the earthquake gets a new life. And a village breaks ground on a center for washing and storing mangoes.
item.title: #191: Good News From Haiti

item.description: And why, in the developing world, it's so tough for the tire repairman to get a loan.
item.title: #190: The Billionaire And The Tire Repairman

item.description: And why a photo of steel wool that looks like a tornado costs $1,265.We wade into the economics of the art world.
item.title: #189: Why A Dead Shark Costs $12 Million

item.description: The easy credit that led to the financial crisis was a fiscal Band-Aid, according to one economist. As economic inequality rose in the U.S., borrowing allowed people to feel richer.
item.title: Deep Read: 'Let Them Eat Credit'

item.description: Alex Blumberg reports from Jamaica, where low-tech tomato farmers struggle to compete.
item.title: #188: Tomatoes, Tradition And The Global Economy

item.description: Some economists want resource-rich countries to give money directly to the people. So far, they haven't found any takers.
item.title: #187: Too Much Lithium Is Depressing

item.description: The people selling rice in the market in Port-au-Prince say business is terrible. We travel to l'Artibonite, Haiti's rice country, to learn more.
item.title: #186: Haiti's Rice Market Is A Mess. Farmers' Kids Go Hungry.

item.description: Why do regulators often wind up partying with the regulated?
item.title: #185: Sex, Drugs And Regulation

item.description: In high-frequency trading, a millionth of a second can be worth $1 million a day.
item.title: #184: The Million-Dollar Microsecond

item.description: India is a nation of a handful of billionaires — and 400 million people without electricity.
item.title: #183: India's Economy Is Booming, But Not For Everybody

item.description: That was a dream Kay Fishburn had back in the '80s. It didn't pan out.
item.title: #182: What If Everybody Chipped In To Pay Off The National Debt?

item.description: Everybody makes a t-shirt. But we want to make a cool t-shirt. A shirt you'll wear for something other than going to the gym. And we need your help.
item.title: #181: Can A Public Radio Shirt Be Cool?

item.description: "When this bill becomes law, the joyride on Wall Street will come to a screeching halt," Harry Reid said last week, after the Senate passed its big finance reform bill.
item.title: #180: Is The Joyride On Wall Street Really Over?

item.description: We bought Toxie — our mortgage-backed toxic asset for $1,000 early this year. The mortgages she's made of were going sour at an alarming rate. When enough of the mortgages went bad, she would die. Right now it looks like she's in a coma.
item.title: #179: Zero Dollars, Zero Cents

item.description: Payday lenders spring up on every corner. But despite the increased competition, their rates stay the same. An economist explains.
item.title: #178: Inside A Payday Loan Shop

item.description: There's this weird thing in the movie business: Almost all movies lose money. Except they don't, really. On today's Planet Money, Edward Jay Epstein, author of The Hollywood Economist, explains the business of movies.
item.title: #177: We See Angelina's Bottom Line

item.description: In Athens, everybody has a story about the easy money that flowed when the country joined the euro. In Newport Beach, a giant bond fund decides when to make the money flow — and when to turn off the spigot.
item.title: #176: Athens And The Bond Kings Of Newport Beach

item.description: We go behind the scenes at Standard & Poor's to answer a question that's been on our mind lately: How do you rate a country?
item.title: #175: When BB+ Is A Bad Grade

item.description: A while back, CNBC anchor Maria Bartiromo trademarked her nickname: "Money Honey." There was talk of an educational show for kids, maybe a Web site. But she apparently lost interest in using the name, and she let the trademark lapse. Sensing the...
item.title: #174: Planet Money, Honey

item.description: In Jamaica, people don't fear the tax collector. On today's Planet Money, we hear from Kimala Bennett, an entrepreneur who decided that should change.
item.title: #173: Fear And Taxes In Jamaica

item.description: David Kestenbaum talks about bribery and payoffs in India. There's the $3.30 a cab driver has to pay a cop to keep from getting a ticket. The $13 you can pay a "broker" to help you get a driver's license — no hassle!
item.title: #171: The Economics Of Bribing A Cop

item.description: We dive into the SEC's lawsuit against Goldman Sachs, and Goldman's emphatic arguments in its defense. And we continue our long quest to unite financial reporting with Broadway theater.

item.description: An toxic asset — very much like our own Toxie — goes bad. And a New Jersey carpenters' union fund that bought a piece of the asset tries to figure out if there's someone to blame.

item.description: In a rare broadcast interview, the president of the New York Fed says regulators should do more to identify and fight bubbles.

item.description: The mall is one of the many, many assets the Fed bought to bail out Bear Stearns a few years back. The assets were bundled into a special company called Maiden Lane I.
item.title: #166: The Fed Wants To Sell You A Mall In Oklahoma

item.description: So there was a big shipping bubble that inflated about the same time the housing bubble did. It grew for some similar reasons — a go-go economy, easy credit, a belief that prices never decline, etc. And, like housing, it's now turned ugly.
item.title: #165: Shipping Is Underwater

item.description: On today's podcast, we visit with Lynn Tilton, head of a $7 billion private-equity fund. And we go inside Spiegel, the catalog company Tilton's firm bought last year.

item.description: Millions of uninsured people will get health insurance. Millions will pay higher taxes. But the broader issue of rising health costs will remain a problem.
